chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then pass in a day of the week such as Monday.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So is Sunday the weekend?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That is true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Monday?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That is false?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Saturday?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That is true. And we do have a wild card case if there are no matches.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is pizza a day of the weekend? That is false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There is a way we can modify this match case too. We tend to be repeating ourselves a lot.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The day is Monday through Friday all return false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We are going to use the or logical operator which is represented with a vertical bar.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If the case of Saturday or Sunday return true,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: if the case is Monday or Tuesday,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: you can get rid of that or Wednesday.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Or Thursday,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: or Friday,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then we will return false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can keep our wild card case.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So is Saturday,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: part of the weekend. That is true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is Monday?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: False? Sunday?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: True?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Friday?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: False?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And pizza?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have our wild card case. That gives us false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Alright everybody, so those are match case statements.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They are similar to switches and other programming languages.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They are an alternative to using many L-SIF statements.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We execute some code if a value matches a case.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The benefits is that the code is cleaner and the syntax is more readable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And while everybody, those are match case statements in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hello friends, it's me again. Today I'm going to explain modules.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A module is just a Python file containing code you want to include in your program.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You use the import keyword to include a module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can use built-in modules or create your own.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Sometimes it's useful to break up a large program in two reusable separate files.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For a list of all the modules found within the standard Python library,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: you can use the help function, pass in the word modules, and then we would need to print this.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here are many of the different modules available to you.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A few you may recognize would be math, string, time.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: One of my favorite names of a module is the pickle module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Unfortunately, it doesn't have anything to do with pickles.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's used for serialization.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To list all of the different variables and functions found within a module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: you can place that name of the module within the help function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For example, with the math module, here are a few different variables we would have access to,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: and a few different functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To include a module, we would type import the name of the module, for example, math.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I now have accessed everything found within the math module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: including those variables and functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To access those variables and functions, I would normally type the name of the module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: dot the name of the variable or function, such as pi.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then let's print this.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Pi from the math module is 3.14 and some change.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Another way to import is to type import the name of the module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: as you can give your module a nickname and alias.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Whatever you think of, such as m, m short for math,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would no longer refer to this module as math.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We would refer to it as our alias.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using an alias would reduce some of the typing you have to use if you have a very long module name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Another way to import is to use from the name of the module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: import something specific.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Pi, for instance, you would no longer need the module name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: From math, import pi, pi would be included within our namespace.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: However, I tend to not use from import as much,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: just because it's possible there could be name conflicts.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's an example.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say from math, import e, e is an exponential constant.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What if I was to create a program where we have four variables named a, b, c, d,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: a equals 1, b equals 2, c equals 3, d equals 4.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I'm going to print e from the math module to the power of a.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would give me 2.71.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then let's do this with b, c, and d.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: e to the power of b, e to the power of c, e to the power of d.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here are the results.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say we have a different variable, e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: e will be 5.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I will print e to the power of e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have imported e from the math module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: When we have declared all of these variables, technically what we've done is we have created

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: another version of e. We will end up using the second version, rather than the version

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: that we have imported from the math module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All my results are now different, and it's possible you may not realize it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I like to be more explicit.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to import math if I'm using a variable or function from a module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I much prefer to prefix that variable name or function with the name of the module in which it's from.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: math.e to the power of a, to the power of b, to the power of c, to the power of d,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: math.e to the power of our variable e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And these results are to be expected.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now to create a module, what we're going to do is right-click on our project folder,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: go to new, python file, think of a module name, maybe example, then click python file,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we now have two tabs, main and example, declare whatever you would like within this module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's create our own variable pi.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: pi equals 3.14159.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then a few functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's create a function to square and argument that's passed in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Define square, we will accept an argument which we will name x, then return x to the power of 2.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's define a cube function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will accept one argument, then return x to the power of 3.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe a circumference function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Define circumference, we will accept a radius, then return 2 times pi times radius,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then an area function to calculate the area of a circle.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will accept a radius as an argument, then return pi times radius to the power of 2.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right, here is our example module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within our main python program, let's import the name of our module, which we named example.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We now have access to everything within this module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to declare a variable result and set it to the name of my module,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: dot pi, then I will print the result, which is 3.14159.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's utilize the square function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Result equals example dot square, let's square 3, which is 9.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's use the cube function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would be 27 circumference.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would give me 18.8, then area,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: that would be 28.2.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's how to create your own module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It can be useful at times to separate your program into individual files.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right, everybody, in conclusion, a module is just a file containing code.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You want to include in your program.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You use import to include a module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can use built-in modules or create your own.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you do need a list of the modules available to you, again, you can use the help function,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then pass in the word modules.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And while everybody, that's how to get started with modules in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey friends, it's me again.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Today, I'm going to explain both variable scope and scope resolution.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Variable scope is where a variable is both visible and accessible.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With scope resolution, when we're using a variable,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: there is a certain order known as the ledgb rule in which we locate that variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Local enclosed, global, built-in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll get to this momentarily.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's begin with variable scope.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I have two functions, function one, function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within function one, a equals one, then we print a, within function two,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: b equals two, then we print b.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I were to invoke these functions, let's invoke function one,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We would print one, then two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Variables declared within a function have a local scope.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Variable a is local to function one,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: variable b is local to function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within function one, if I were to print b, and function two, if I were to print a,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would run into a name error.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Name b is not defined, and the same thing would apply with a.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Functions can't see inside of other functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Imagine that we're function one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is our house.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can see everything that's going on inside of our house,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: but function two is our neighbor's house.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can't see what's going on inside of our neighbor's house.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have no idea what b is.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With function two, function two has no idea what a is.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's where variable scope comes in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's where a variable is visible and accessible.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Functions can't see inside of other functions,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: but they can see inside of their own function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's why we sometimes pass arguments two functions,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: so that our functions are aware of them.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using this concept, we could create different versions of the same variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's rename a to be x, and b to be x as well.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I will print x.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have two different versions of x.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A local version of x found within function one,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: and a local version of x found within function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Whenever we utilize a variable,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we will first look to see if there's any local instance of that variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If there isn't, we would move to the enclosed scope.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With an enclosed scope, one example is when you have a function

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: declared within another function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to place function two within function one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is allowed in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is a more advanced concept.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll cover this more in the future.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I'm going to eliminate this print statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's get rid of function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: At the end of function one, we will invoke function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Like I said, it's pretty complex.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We won't be using this until much later.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within function two, if I was to print x,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would use the local version, or x equals two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I was to eliminate this variable declaration,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would use the enclosed version instead, where x equals one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There's an order of operations.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Use any local variables first, then enclosed variables.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're printing x within function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Since x wasn't found within the local scope,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would use x within the enclosed scope.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But like I said, that's a more advanced topic.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You should at least be aware of it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's move on to the global scope,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: global meaning outside of any functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will eliminate these variable declarations.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within function one, we're printing x,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: and within function two, we're also printing x.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will declare a global version of x, where x equals three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: x is outside of any functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: When I run this program, we're printing three twice,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: once for function one, and once for function two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There's no longer a local version of x for both of these functions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If there were, we would end up using these local versions instead.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Function one, prints one, function two, prints two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If there's no local version, as well as no enclosed version,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: we would move on to the global version, where x equals three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Last in our order is built in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I think what we'll do, though, is from math, import e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: e is an exponential constant.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to print what e is.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: e is built in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will create a function to print e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Define function one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All I'm doing is printing e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we should invoke it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Invoke function one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I was to set e to be a different value,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: like three, what we're doing technically is creating two different versions of e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Variables can share the same name as long as they're within a different scope.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have a built-in version of e and a global version of e.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I was to print e now, it would print my global version.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Because using the ledgb order, we would first look for any local version of e,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then enclosed version, then global, which we do have one of, then lastly built in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right, everybody.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So in conclusion, variable scope is just where a variable is both visible and accessible.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Python has a scope resolution order,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: ledgb.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we're using a variable, we will first look in the local scope for that variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we don't find that variable in the local scope, we will move over to an enclosed scope,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then global, then built in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will have more practice with this in the future.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And while everybody, that is both variable scope and scope resolution in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey, everybody.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So today I got to talk about this if statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If dundername is equal to a string of dundermain,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: when you see this if statement, it's usually followed by a call to a function named main,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: or something similar.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A majority of the driving code behind a program is usually found within some sort of main method.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: When you see this if statement, basically speaking it means that this script can be imported,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: or it can run standalone.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Functions in classes in this module can be reused in other programs

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: without the main block of code running.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Sometimes you would like the functionality of a program without executing the main body of code.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A good example could be a library in a
